an3.30:4.1: “These three people are found in the world.
an3.30:4.3: One with upside-down wisdom, one with wisdom on their lap, and one with wide wisdom.
an3.30:4.4: And who is the person with upside-down wisdom?
an3.30:4.5: It’s someone who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:4.6: The mendicants teach them Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they explain a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:4.7: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:4.8: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:4.9: It’s like when a pot full of water is tipped over, so the water drains out and doesn’t stay.
an3.30:4.10: So too, someone often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:4.11: The mendicants teach them Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they explain a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:4.12: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t pay attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, or end.
an3.30:4.13: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:4.14: This is called a person with upside-down wisdom.
an3.30:5.1: And who is the person with wisdom on their lap?
an3.30:5.2: It’s someone who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:5.3: The mendicants teach them Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they explain a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:5.4: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:5.5: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:5.6: It’s like a person who has different kinds of food crammed on their lap—
an3.30:5.7: such as sesame, rice, sweets, or jujube—
an3.30:5.8: so that if they get up from the seat without mindfulness, everything gets scattered.
an3.30:5.9: So too, someone often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:5.10: The mendicants teach them Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they explain a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:5.11: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:5.12: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:5.13: This is called a person with wisdom on their lap.
an3.30:6.1: And who is the person with wide wisdom?
an3.30:6.2: It’s someone who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:6.3: The mendicants teach them Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they explain a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:6.4: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:6.5: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:6.6: It’s like when a pot full of water is set straight, so the water stays and doesn’t drain out.
an3.30:6.7: So too, someone often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:6.8: The mendicants teach them Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they explain a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:6.9: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:6.10: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:6.11: This is called a person with wide wisdom.
an3.30:6.12: These are the three people found in the world.”
an3.30:9.1: The person with wisdom on their lap
an3.30:9.2: is better than that, it’s said;
an3.30:10.1: such a person can only learn
an3.30:10.4: but they’ve only grasped the phrasing,
an3.30:10.5: for when they get up their understanding fails,
an3.30:10.6: and what they’ve learned is lost.
an3.30:11.2: is better than that, it’s said;
an3.30:12.4: and when they’ve grasped the phrasing,
an3.30:13.1: they remember it with the best of intentions.
an3.30:13.3: practicing in line with the teaching,
an3.30:13.4: would make an end of suffering.”
